title: Configure Native SACM with Studio
content:
With Native SACM enabled, you can use Studio to manage your SACM record types and relationships federated from UCMDB.

Add new federated attributes

To add additional federated attributes into Service Management, go to the SACM record type where new fields are required and add a custom attribute to the record type.

During the creation of a custom attribute, specify the attribute details. There is now a new flag called “Federated Attribute.” Activate the flag and select a UCMDB attribute to associate with from the drop down list. The drop down list includes a list of UCMDB attributes for the federated CI types.

You can also add these new attributes directly to the forms.

In case newly created attributes in UD/UCMDB don't appear in the UD/UCMDB property name list, restart the API Gateway.

Use federated attributes in business rules

In Service Management business rules, you can use federated SACM fields/attributes from UCMDB and the changes made by business rules will be federated to UCMDB instantly.

Use business rules to create or delete CI relationships

When Native SACM is enabled, you can open an Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element record, click the Related CIs tab to view the CI topology federated from UCMDB. At the Service Management end, in addition to creating or deleting CI relationships in the service modeling widget, you can also create and run business rules in order to do so.

Currently, the following actions are supported by business rules:

  • Create Composition, Containment, or Usage relationships between two federated SACM records.
  • Delete Composition, Containment, or Usage relationships between two federated SACM records.

Note: CI relationships other than Composition, Containment, and Usage are also federated from UCMDB to SMA, however, they cannot be managed by SMAX business rules. 

Note: Although CI relationships only exist among SACM records, you can create a business rule in any records to create a CI relationship between SACM records. For example, you can create a business rule in the Request record type, which isn't a SACM record type, and use this business rule to create a CI relationship between a Device record and an Actual Service record, which are SACM records.

Create a CI relationship with a business rule

You can create a CI relationship with either a simple or "If...Then" rule.

To create a CI relationship with a business rule:

  1. Select a record type in Studio.
  2. On Processes and Rules tab, in a desired process event, click Add, select either Simple rule or "If...Then" rule.
  3. Select the Create CI relationship action.
  4. Enter the If condition with a DSL expression if it's an "If...Then" rule.
  5. In the Create CI relationship of type <relationship type> from <record type 1> with ID <id 1> to <record type 2> with ID <id 2> action, populate the following fields:
    • <relationship type>: Select Composition, Containment, or Usage.
    • <record type 1>: Select the source SACM record type, which can be Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element.
    • <id 1>: Select the source SACM record.
    • <record type 2>: Select the target SACM record type, which can be Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element.
    • <id 2>: Select the target SACM record.
  6. When this rule is run, a CI relationship is created from record <id 1> to record <id2> in UCMDB.

Delete a CI relationship with a business rule

You can delete a CI relationship with either a simple or "If...Then" rule.

To delete a CI relationship with a business rule:

  1. Select a record type in Studio.
  2. On Processes and Rules tab, in a desired process event, click Add, select either Simple rule or "If...Then" rule.
  3. Select the Delete CI relationship action.
  4. Enter the If condition with a DSL expression if it's an "If...Then" rule.
  5. In the Delete CI relationship of type <relationship type> from <record type 1> with ID <id 1> to <record type 2> with ID <id 2> action, populate the following fields:
    • <relationship type>: Select Composition, Containment, or Usage.
    • <record type 1>: Select the source SACM record type, which can be Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element.
    • <id 1>: Select the source SACM record.
    • <record type 2>: Select the target SACM record type, which can be Actual Service, Device, Service Component, or System Element.
    • <id 2>: Select the target SACM record.
  6. When this rule is run, a CI relationship is deleted from record <id 1> to record <id2> in UCMDB.

Run business rule through a record's task plan to create or delete CI relationships

Business rules can also be run through a record's task plan. Therefore, it's also possible to create or delete a CI relationship by setting a business rule within a record's task plan when available. The syntax of the Create CI relationship and Delete CI relationship actions is the same as described above.

Note: Only simple business rules are supported in task plans, if a condition needed, you can use the Decision field of the task plan. For more information about task plans, see Task plans.

Use Native SACM status in a business rule condition

You can use the tenant_settings.ENABLE_CMSX property in a business rule condition, its value can be true (Native SACM is enabled in tenant application settings) or false (Native SACM is not enabled in tenant application settings).

For example, the following condition allows the business rule to be run only when Native SACM is enabled:

If ${tenant_settings.ENABLE_CMSX == true}
